bibl.title: Letter from Alberto Recio to Philip Showalter Hench, December 13, 1941

div1.p: Recio thanks Hench for some reprints on the transmission of yellow fever and a copy of Cornwell's painting. He believes that the discovery belongs to Finlay but that the glory should be shared with the American Commission who confirmed his findings.

div1.head: Letter from Alberto Recio to Philip Showalter Hench, December 13, 1941
div1.opener:
Ave de la Independencia y Montoro
DR. ALBERTO RECIO
HABANA
December 13, 1941
Dr. P. S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I have received your kind letter of
Nov. 20th. and the reprints of your excellent histo-
rical article on the discovery of the transmission of
yellow fever by the mosquito, including a very nice
color copy of Cornwell's picture.

I think it is a very fine contribu-
tion to the better understanding of the rôle played
in that great achievement by each of the actors who
took part. I believe there is no question that the great
discovery belongs to Finlay but that be must share the
glory not only with the members of the American Com-
mission who so admirably confirmed his findings and
those heroic volunteers who offered themselves as gui-
nea-pigs, some of them even giving their lives, but al-
so with those who applied the methods recommended by
the Cuban investigator in fighting yellow fever and ob-
tained such a big success in such short time.

I must also congratulate you on your
noble work of trying to erase the discrepancies which
should have never existed among scientific men.
